title: Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season : scientists | iNFOnews
message:
Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season: scientistsScientists say tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO — Amanda Dunfield, *MANDATORY CREDIT*Original Publication Date July 31, 2024 - 1:01 AMHALIFAX - Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
"You can see it in the atmosphere, moving from Africa westward across the Atlantic," says Chris Fogarty, manager of the Canadian Hurricane Centre in Dartmouth, N.S.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.
In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

message:
HALIFAX – Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year’s Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
Scientists say tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
Only three named storms have formed over the Atlantic since hurricane season started on June 1 — tropical storms Alberto and Chris, and hurricane Beryl, which on July 2 became the earliest Category 5 hurricane to be recorded over the Atlantic.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.

title: Know your flood risk and act now
message:
One government agency is urging residents to understand their flood risk and act now.
But the crucial question remains, how can you determine your flood risk and what steps should you take?
FEMA Deputy Assistant and Federal Insurance Administrator, Jeff Jackson, emphasizes that the first, crucial step is to assess your flood risk.
But why is it necessary to purchase flood insurance now if peak hurricane season isn’t until September?
It’s important to note that when it comes to flood insurance your claim could be denied if only your home is affected.

title: Vermont man evacuates neighbors during flooding , weeks after witnessing a driver get swept away
message:
LYNDON, Vt. (AP) — Weeks after Jason Pilbin witnessed a driver get swept away by floodwaters, his northeastern Vermont community was ravaged again by flooding from heavy rains.
Nearly three weeks ago, he watched helplessly as a man drowned after getting caught while driving through floodwaters from Hurricane Beryl.
More heavy rains were in the forecast for the state on Wednesday with the possibility of flash flooding.
The fresh flooding yielded similar scenes of catastrophe as the flooding weeks earlier in which two people died, but on a smaller scale.
It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.

title: This Is Considered the Worst July Storm in Kentucky History
message:
As I await the return of the electricity, I thought I'd do a little digging into the history of July storms in Kentucky.
The Weather Channel's data indicates the '22 flood in Eastern Kentucky was the nation's deadliest non-tropical flash flood in 45 years.
The Worst July Storm in Kentucky's HistoryBut it was back in 1939 when Kentucky incurred the wrath of what would come to be classified by the National Weather Service as the worst July storm in the Commonwealth's history.
Additionally, the rapidly rising waters destroyed the Kentucky Mountain Bible Institute which was rebuilt as the Kentucky Mountain Bible College.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake jolts Tokyo area : JMA
message:
Tokyo, July 31 : An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on early Wednesday rocked the Tokyo metropolitan area, the country's weather agency said.
The temblor occurred at 01:47 a.m. local time, measuring 3 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in areas in Tokyo, Kanagawa and Chiba Prefecture, said the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).
At a depth of 120 km, the epicentre was located in Tokyo's 23 wards at a latitude of 35.7 degrees north and a longitude of 139.6 degrees east, Xinhua news agency reported.
The tremors were felt strongly in central Tokyo, with no tsunami warnings issued.
There have been no reports of damage or casualties due to the temblor.

message:

Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.

title: Hurricane Preparedness Forum in Avon , NWS expects above average storm season
message:
HATTERAS VILLAGE, NC — Hurricanes are nothing new for Outer Banks residents, but the National Weather Service is expecting an above average storm season and with the Dare County Department of Emergency Management, are hosting Hurricane Preparedness Forums around OBX.
Watch: NWS hurricane preparedness forums coming to the Outer BanksHow the Outer Banks prepares for hurricanesMore than 30 Hatteras residents piled into the Avon Volunteer Fire Department for the forum Tuesday afternoon.
Hurricane season is every year from May to October, but the peak of it is usually in September.
Watch: Outer Banks prepares for weekend's coastal storm impactOuter Banks prepares for weekend's coastal storm impactOne resident attending has been coming to the Outer Banks for decades, but just moved here full-time in 2023.
The next Hurricane Preparedness Forum will be held in-person and online at the Dare County Emergency Operations Center in Manteo on Wednesday from 10 a.m. to 11:30 a.m.

title: Hurricane center ups chances to 60 % tropical system could form , threaten Florida
message:
ORLANDO, Fla. — The National Hurricane Center increased the odds a system developing in the Atlantic could turn into the season’s next tropical depression or storm with a projected path that could threaten Florida.
“There is some potential for a tropical depression to form late this week in the vicinity of the Bahamas.”The NHC’s wide swath of the system’s potential path shifted north and farther east since Monday but all of Florida’s peninsula remains in the potential path.

Hurricane season officially runs from June 1-Nov. 30.

title: CenterPoint wants $1 billion - plus Hurricane Beryl recovery costs to be covered by Houston - area customers – Houston Public Media
message:
CenterPoint EnergyIt took a matter of hours, maybe even minutes, for Hurricane Beryl to knock out electricity for more than 2.2 million customers in the Houston region.
CenterPoint CEO Jason Wells acknowledged during a special Texas Senate committee hearing Monday that the utility company plans to pass its recovery costs onto its 2.8 million customers in the Houston area.
State Sen. Carol Alvarado, a Houston Democrat, asked Wells whether CenterPoint would ask for a rate increase to recoup its storm recovery costs.
CenterPoint intends to increase their rates to recoup the cost of recovering from Hurricane Beryl, passing the cost on to the customer.
Texas also needs a better system for allowing utility companies to recoup their infrastructure and storm recovery costs, that do not correlate to increased costs for customers, according to Haverlah.

title: Foster + Partners unveils plan for rebuilding Antakya post - earthquake
message:
British architecture studio Foster + Partners has revealed its masterplan to rebuild Antakya, Turkey, following the Turkey-Syria earthquakes last year.
According to Foster + Partners, around 80 per cent of the buildings in Antakya were damaged in the earthquake.
"Before the earthquake, the city of Antakya faced some challenges that we aim to address during the sustainable reconstruction," said Foster + Partners partner Loukia Iliopoulou.
Foster + Partners plans to begin rebuilding in one area of Antakya, starting with building the high streets to establish homes near places of employment.

title: Political Spin : Irresponsible forest management spawns catastrophic fires
message:
A column by Bruce UzelmanJasper, Alberta is the latest community to experience catastrophic wildfire.
Forest management policies, beginning in the early 1900s, prioritized fire suppression to preserve valuable timber and reforestation with the most commercially valuable species, which were coniferous, particularly pine.
The disastrous fire at Jasper demonstrates the impact of past and present forest management.
B.C.’s Forest Practices Board recommends “landscape forest management,” to provide protection against aggressive wildfire.
Rather, without extensive reform, Jasper is the first of many catastrophic wildfires that will befall Canada’s west in 2024 and beyond.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake jolts Tokyo area : JMA - Xinhua
message:
TOKYO, July 31 (Xinhua) -- An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on early Wednesday rocked the Tokyo metropolitan area, the country's weather agency said.
The temblor occurred at 01:47 a.m. local time, measuring 3 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in areas in Tokyo, Kanagawa and Chiba Prefecture, said the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).
At a depth of 120 km, the epicenter was located in Tokyo's 23 wards at a latitude of 35.7 degrees north and a longitude of 139.6 degrees east.
The tremors were felt strongly in central Tokyo, with no tsunami warnings issued.
There have been no reports of damage or casualties due to the temblor.

Unlike our sanitary sewer system, stormwater runoff is not treated but discharged directly into our creeks and streams, along with the pollutants it grabbed along the way.

title: Is this Chinese AI model a seismic change in earthquake prediction ?
message:

He said DiTing was based on more data than the STEAD model, a commonly used seismic data set developed by Stanford University researchers in 2019.
While STEAD covered around 450,000 earthquakes between 1984 and 2018, DiTing used data covering 787,010 earthquakes from 2013 to 2020 in China.
Researchers said the model could also be used in fields such as mine seismic monitoring, shale gas exploitation, urban underground space structure detection and underwater earthquake monitoring.

title: Torrential rain expected Wednesday in Vermont following another  historic  storm
message:
Large swaths of Vermont are expected to receive heavy rainfall Wednesday.
It issued a flood watch for all but the southernmost counties of Windham and Bennington from noon Wednesday through midnight.
Even an inch of rain an hour in those locations could pose problems, according to Duell.
Vermont has experienced a spate of extreme weather of late, including major flooding throughout central and northeastern parts of the state on July 10 and 11.
Vermont Emergency Management was monitoring Wednesday’s expected thunderstorms, according to spokesperson Mark Bosma, but had not yet taken any unusual measures.

title: Wildfire smoke linked to heightened risk of dementia diagnosis , new California research finds
message:
New study finds odds of dementia diagnosis increased by wildfire smoke particles New study finds odds of dementia diagnosis increased by wildfire smoke particles 03:00SACRAMENTO -- When a wildfire rips through your community, your life and home are likely top of mind, but what about your brain health?
A new study released Monday, at the Alzheimer's Association International Conference found that wildfire smoke is linked to heightened risk of a new dementia diagnosis.
Exposure to non-wildfire PM2.5 does still come with an elevated dementia risk, but not as high as wildfire smoke.
It's not as simple as narrowing it down to people who live in areas prone to wildfire, considering wildfire smoke travels.
What should people do in their homes to protect from the wildfire smoke and its impact on their health?

title: Earthquake rattles New Jersey : USGS
message:
CALIFON, N.J. (PIX11) – A 2.2-magnitude earthquake rattled New Jersey early Wednesday morning, according to the United States Geological Survey.
The earthquake struck around 12:45 a.m. nearly 35 miles away from Trenton.
More Local NewsThe earthquake’s epicenter was 3 miles away from Califon, which has a population of just over 1,000, according to the USGS.
A 4.8-magnitude earthquake struck near the same area in New Jersey back in April, causing buildings across New Jersey and New York City to sway.
Approximately 42 million people felt the earthquake, per the USGS.

title: How wildfire smoke raises your risk of dementia
message:
The Summary Studies have found that wildfire smoke negatively affects brain health.
“A lot of the research on wildfire smoke has historically focused on our lungs and our hearts,” said Stephanie Cleland, an assistant professor at Simon Fraser University who studies the health impacts of wildfire smoke.
Scientists think the reason wildfire smoke affects the brain is that the tiny particles within it can cross the barrier between the bloodstream and the brain, causing inflammation in the central nervous system.
Other research published the same year showed that exposure to wildfire smoke during the school year reduced students’ test scores relative to a year with no smoke.
“Last summer completely changed our conversation around who’s exposed to wildfire smoke,” she said.

title: 2 . 2 magnitude earthquake recorded in New Jersey near Califon , Hunterdon County

This is the sixth earthquake recorded this month in New Jersey.
Five of the six have been near Califon, while a 2.0 magnitude tremor was recorded near New Egypt in Ocean County on July 6.
Jersey has been feeling tremors -- or aftershocks -- ever since a 4.8 magnitude earthquake shook the Northeast in April.

title: Winston - Salem remains in severe drought , despite rain
message:
As drought persists across the state, Winston-Salem is experiencing its second-driest start to summer in the past 26 years.
The U.S. Drought Monitor’s weekly update last week showed Greensboro has improved from a severe drought to a moderate drought classification due to recent heavy and widespread rainfall.
Winston-Salem remains in severe drought marking the city’s third consecutive week in the severe drought designation.
Greensboro has had 6.79 inches of rain, just 0.63 inches below average, which explains the uneven recovery from drought conditions in the region.
This persistent dryness and the early onset of drought conditions are part of a broader pattern influenced by climate change.

title: Google Maps and Search gets wildfire alerts in more countries
message:
Google Maps is one of the company’s most comprehensive services.
In addition to Maps, Google Search is also compatible with the feature.
Maps and Search services have been showing alerts for nearby wildfire boundaries since 2020.
Now, the wildfire alert system through Google Maps and Search is also available in the following countries: Andorra, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Croatia, Cyprus, France, Greece, Italy, Kenya, Monaco, Montenegro, Portugal, Rwanda, Slovenia, Spain, and Turkey.
The Mountain View giant has been deploying the feature in regions that “have been impacted by wildfires in recent summers.” Lastly, Google also says that Maps and Search wildfire alerts will be available in more countries in the future.
